OK -- I guess I'll be the one to go in where angels fear to tread!  
-- LOL=
 --  I will limit my comments to the two organizations I have 
personal exp=
erience with having no predjudice toward any others.

First, I would sugges=
t reading through this link:

http://www.nihonto.ca/ratings.html

Darcy Bro=
ckbank did a great job going over the organizations ratings 
systems and al=
though aimed at swords it crosses over to fittings well.

Basically both or=
ganizations are excellent and their papers are given 
high regard internati=
onally and their shinsa teams are both top 
notch.  It has been 'my' experi=
ence that if you are papering for 
authentication with insight into details=
 then the NTHK might be more 
appropriate as they rate by point and give de=
scription sheets with 
pertinent information (I believe this is only at the=
ir US shinsa and 
does not apply to the ones held in Japan).  The NBTHK is =
the larger 
organization and perhaps has the advantage of greater popular 
=
recognition/charisma but their papers do not have the worksheets to 
supply=
 information and that listed on their origami (paper) can be 
limited. It i=
s also a consideration that the NBTHK papers tend to be 
more expensive to =
obtain.  I have both and have submitted for both -- 
both organizations are=
 worthy of our support.  

As far as submission (assuming you live outside =
of Japan) for the 
NBTHK you will need an agent to submit and would be best=
 served going 
through one of the dealer/agents you can find on-line and/or=
 by 
recommendation.  The NTHK has shinsa here in the USA and it would be 
=
well worth your while to go to the shinsa/show (in Chicago this 
Spring) an=
d be part of the process.  They will have a question/answer 
session after =
the close of the day's session which is very 
informative.  You also have a=
 show to attend in the meantime which 
will give you great contacts and man=
y ways to spend your savings! 
(LOL)  If you simply can't go then there are=
 again dealer agents who 
can assist you. 

I would strongly suggest that a=
nyone who has the ability to attend 
the Chicago Show/Shinsa do so.  This i=
s a 'hands-on' field and you 
need all the first hand experience you can ge=
t.  Books are a far 
second to what you can learn in person.  Be patient as=
 it takes some 
time to become known and make contacts.  In the long run th=
e faces 
will become familiar (for better or worse - LOL) and you will find=
 
your 'niche'.  I guarantee it can be time well spent.  Bottom line is 
ge=
t full immersion in the field by hands on experience 
whenever/wherever pos=
sible, keep an open mind, respect your elders, 
wash behind your ears and l=
eave the fine tuning for later.
